Topic.Title: Question for 'popular vote' enthusiasts who thought Gore should have been President

Message.Msg: Treasury rejects Issa subpoena threat on health care Rep. Darrell Issa is shown. | Jay Westcott/POLITICO 'Federal exchange subsidies may cost taxpayers in excess of $500 billion,' Issa said. | Jay Westcott/POLITICO By JASON MILLMAN | 10/26/12 5:33 PM EDT Updated: 10/26/12 7:14 PM EDT The Treasury Department, rejecting a subpoena threat from the House Oversight and Government Reform Committee, is citing executive branch “confidentiality interests” in its refusal to turn over documents on an IRS rule allowing subsidies in federal health insurance exchanges. “Obamacare” opponents argue that the law only allows subsidies to flow through state-run health exchanges — the new marketplaces for health insurance that are supposed to begin in 2014 — and that the IRS rule oversteps legal bounds. Under the law, the Department of Health and Human Services is supposed to set up federal exchanges in states that don’t build their own. Reid doing fine after car accident Agency officials this summer defended the rule before two House committees, contending that an entire reading of the law clearly intended for the subsidies to be available in federal exchanges, too. The Oversight panel had ordered the IRS and Treasury to turn over documents by Thursday that would shed light on how the agencies formed the legal basis for the subsidy rule. Instead, the Treasury claimed that the executive branch needs to keep those documents private. “It is well-established that agency staff and counsel must have the ability to engage in free, full, and unfettered discussions and debate about important policy and legal matters,” wrote Alastair Fitzpayne, Treasury assistant secretary for legislative affairs. “Accordingly, as the Executive Branch has long maintained, public disclosure of such material could have a significant chilling effect on agency staff and could inhibit their ability to fulfill their statutory responsibilities.” The Treasury letter asserts that the department’s interpretation should be settled “through the judicial process,” referencing a lawsuit that Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt filed against the IRS rule last month. Though the Oversight committee threatened a subpoena earlier this week, a Friday afternoon statement from Chairman Darrell Issa (R-Calif.) didn’t indicate how the panel would respond to Treasury’s refusal to turn over the documents. “Federal exchange subsidies may cost taxpayers in excess of $500 billion over the next decade,” Issa said. “The Administration’s refusal to shed light on the development of this half-trillion dollar extra-legal rule is stunning.”

Message.Title: Surface is a joke
Message.Msg: I got mine yesterday. What is this thing? Ultrabooks have nicer screens, weigh about as much (maybe less), have faster procs / graphics chips, better screens, and far more applications. The Surface needs its own compiled apps and is not directly compatible with the desktop version of Windows 8 (but, at the same time, IS essentially Windows 8)? The thing is a brick. Plus, the power attachment looks the same as the keyboard adapter (I couldn't figure out how to charge the thing). Now, don't laugh, but this is another big problem. With the removal of Flash, it doesn't support the major adult websites (youp0rn, p0rnhub, etc.). This is a HUGE part of the tablet market. Metro is exactly that: a blue and purple pile of puke. IMO, this is the UGLIEST UI EVER in the history of computing. I'm going hard core short M$FT on Monday. IMO, Windows 8 is a disaster that will make Vista look like a massive success.

Message.Title: Big problems, small Obama
Message.Msg: October 26, 2012 2:21 PM Big problems, small Obama BY DEREK HUNTER If there’s one thing President Obama wants to avoid discussing this election more than his administration’s impotence on the slaughter in Benghazi, it’s the economy. Unfortunately for him, the economy is the issue people care about most. The President’s record is one of hype and hope trumped by reality. The GDP growth we were promised is less than half of what we’ve gotten. We have a record number of people on food stamps and have averaged 975 people per day, 8.8 million in total, being added to the Social Security disability rolls. The only reason the unemployment rate has dropped is because people have given up hope of finding work and are no longer counted. To call the Obama record on the economy a failure is an indictment of the English language that simply hasn’t created a strong enough word to accurately convey the gap between what we were sold and what we got. The President’s response? Binders, Big Bird and birth control.

Message.Msg: And so would FIFTY THOUSAND INNOCENT WOMEN AND CHILDREN. Too bad liberals have no regard for human life. Or any life for that matter.
